ref.name: Basic Matrix Operations
ref.alt: Basic Matrix Operations
ref.sum: Basic techniques and functions for working with matrices in the MATLAB® language.

ref.name: Fourier Transforms
ref.alt: Fourier Transforms
ref.sum: The Fourier transform is a powerful tool for analyzing data across many applications, including Fourier analysis for signal processing.

ref.name: Create Common 2-D Plots
ref.alt: Create Common 2-D Plots
ref.sum: Create a variety of 2-D plots in MATLAB®.

ref.name: Introduction to the Live Editor
ref.alt: Introduction to the Live Editor
ref.sum: An introduction to the Live Editor. In the Live Editor, you can create live scripts that show output together with the code that produced it. Add formatted text, equations, images, and hyperlinks to enhance your narrative, and share the live script with others as an interactive document.

ref.name: Read Spreadsheet Data into Table
ref.alt: Read Spreadsheet Data into Table
ref.sum: The best way to represent tabular spreadsheet data in MATLAB is in a table since tables can store heterogeneous (a mix of numeric and text) data, as well as variable and row names.

ref.name: Analyze Big Data in MATLAB Using Tall Arrays
ref.alt: Analyze Big Data in MATLAB Using Tall Arrays
ref.sum: Use tall arrays to work with big data in MATLAB®. You can use tall arrays to perform a variety of calculations on different types of data that does not fit in memory. These include basic calculations, as well as machine learning algorithms within Statistics and Machine Learning Toolbox™.

ref.name: Plot Numeric Data in an App
ref.alt: Plot Numeric Data in an App
ref.sum: Example of an App Designer app that uses a button callback to display a line plot.

ref.name: Matrices and Arrays
ref.alt: Matrices and Arrays
ref.sum: MATLAB operates primarily on arrays and matrices, both in whole and in part. A matrix is a two-dimensional array often used for linear algebra.

ref.name: Array Indexing
ref.alt: Array Indexing
ref.sum: Variables in MATLAB are typically arrays that can hold many numbers. When you want to access selected elements of an array, use indexing.

ref.name: Calling Functions
ref.alt: Calling Functions
ref.sum: MATLAB provides a large number of functions that perform computational tasks. To call a function, enclose its input arguments in parentheses.

ref.name: 2-D and 3-D Plots
ref.alt: 2-D and 3-D Plots
ref.sum: Graphics functions include 2-D and 3-D plotting functions to visualize data and communicate results.

ref.name: Calling Functions
ref.alt: Calling Functions
ref.sum: MATLAB provides a large number of functions that perform computational tasks. To call a function, enclose its input arguments in parentheses.

ref.name: Ignore Function Outputs
ref.alt: Ignore Function Outputs
ref.sum: Request specific outputs from a function.

ref.name: Creating, Concatenating, and Expanding Matrices
ref.alt: Creating, Concatenating, and Expanding Matrices
ref.sum: Create a matrix or construct one from other matrices.

ref.name: Array Indexing
ref.alt: Array Indexing
ref.sum: Access elements of an array by specifying their indices or by checking whether elements meet a condition.

ref.name: Find Array Elements That Meet Conditions
ref.alt: Find Array Elements That Meet Conditions
ref.sum: Filter the elements of an array by applying conditions to the array. For instance, you can examine the even elements in a matrix, find the location of all 0s in a multidimensional array, or replace NaN values in data. You can perform these tasks using a combination of the relational and logical operators. The relational operators (>, <, >=, <=, ==, ~=) impose conditions on the array, and you can apply multiple conditions by connecting them with the logical operators and, or, and not, respectively denoted by the symbols &, |, and ~.

ref.name: Access Data in Cell Array
ref.alt: Access Data in Cell Array
ref.sum: Read and write data from and to a cell array.

ref.name: Detailed Rules for Array Indexing
ref.alt: Detailed Rules for Array Indexing
ref.sum: Detailed rules about array indexing to access and modify array elements.

ref.name: Indexed Assignment
ref.alt: Indexed Assignment
ref.sum: Use indexed assignment to modify array elements and enable array growth.

ref.name: Arrays with Dimensions of Size 1
ref.alt: Arrays with Dimensions of Size 1
ref.sum: Arrays with dimensions of size 1.

ref.name: Detailed Rules for Indexed Assignment
ref.alt: Detailed Rules for Indexed Assignment
ref.sum: Detailed rules about indexed assignment to modify array elements.

ref.name: Removing Rows or Columns from a Matrix
ref.alt: Removing Rows or Columns from a Matrix
ref.sum: Remove matrix rows or columns.

ref.name: Reshaping and Rearranging Arrays
ref.alt: Reshaping and Rearranging Arrays
ref.sum: Change the shape or arrangement of elements in an existing array.

ref.name: Multidimensional Arrays
ref.alt: Multidimensional Arrays
ref.sum: Create and manipulate arrays with three or more dimensions.

ref.name: Empty Arrays
ref.alt: Empty Arrays
ref.sum: Create and use empty arrays, which have no elements but have specific dimensions, at least one of which is 0.

ref.name: Single Precision Math
ref.alt: Single Precision Math
ref.sum: Perform arithmetic and linear algebra with single precision data. It also shows how the results are computed appropriately in single-precision or double-precision, depending on the input.

ref.name: Integer Arithmetic
ref.alt: Integer Arithmetic
ref.sum: Perform arithmetic on integer data representing signals and images.

ref.name: Hexadecimal and Binary Values
ref.alt: Hexadecimal and Binary Values
ref.sum: Specify hexadecimal and binary values either as literals or as text. Hexadecimal and binary literals are stored as integers. You can convert text representing hexadecimal and binary values to numbers, and numbers to text representations.

ref.name: Text in String and Character Arrays
ref.alt: Text in String and Character Arrays
ref.sum: Store and manipulate text using either string arrays or character arrays.

ref.name: Create String Arrays
ref.alt: Create String Arrays
ref.sum: Create string arrays to store sequences of characters. String arrays provide a set of functions to work with strings.

ref.name: Analyze Text Data with String Arrays
ref.alt: Analyze Text Data with String Arrays
ref.sum: Analyze text data with string arrays. It shows how to store, split, and sort text, and how to compute and collect statistics for text in a string array.

ref.name: Compare Text
ref.alt: Compare Text
ref.sum: Compare and inspect character arrays and string arrays.

ref.name: Test for Empty Strings and Missing Values
ref.alt: Test for Empty Strings and Missing Values
ref.sum: Test string arrays for empty strings and missing values.

ref.name: Search and Replace Text
ref.alt: Search and Replace Text
ref.sum: MATLAB provides several functions to search for, replace, or extract text in string arrays and character vectors.

ref.name: Build Pattern Expressions
ref.alt: Build Pattern Expressions
ref.sum: Patterns define rules for matching text with text-searching functions.

ref.name: Unicode and ASCII Values
ref.alt: Unicode and ASCII Values
ref.sum: MATLAB stores all characters as Unicode characters. Both strings and character vectors use the same encoding. You can convert characters to their Unicode code values, and numbers to characters.

ref.name: Hexadecimal and Binary Values
ref.alt: Hexadecimal and Binary Values
ref.sum: Specify hexadecimal and binary values either as literals or as text. Hexadecimal and binary literals are stored as integers. You can convert text representing hexadecimal and binary values to numbers, and numbers to text representations.

ref.name: Convert Between Text and datetime or duration Values
ref.alt: Convert Between Text and datetime or duration Values
ref.sum: The datetime and duration data types are the recommended data types for working with dates and times. You can convert these data types to text by using the string function, and you can convert text to these data types by using the datetime and duration functions. When you read text representing dates and times from spreadsheets and text files you can automatically convert the text to datetime or duration arrays.

ref.name: Extract or Assign Date and Time Components of Datetime Array
ref.alt: Extract or Assign Date and Time Components of Datetime Array
ref.sum: Extract date and time components by accessing the array properties or by calling a function. Then, the example shows how to modify the date and time components by modifying the array properties.

ref.name: Compare Dates and Time
ref.alt: Compare Dates and Time
ref.sum: Compare dates, times, and durations by using relational operators, such as >, <, and ==, taking time zones and daylight saving time into account.

ref.name: Date and Time Arithmetic
ref.alt: Date and Time Arithmetic
ref.sum: Add and subtract date and time values to calculate future and past dates and elapsed durations in exact units or calendar units.

ref.name: Plot Dates and Times
ref.alt: Plot Dates and Times
ref.sum: Create plots with data that represents dates and times, using appropriate units and customized labels. Read dates and times from data files and display them in plots.

ref.name: Specify Time Zones
ref.alt: Specify Time Zones
ref.sum: Specify time zones for datetime arrays to account for time zone offsets, daylight saving time, or leap seconds.

ref.name: Convert Date and Time to Julian Date or POSIX Time
ref.alt: Convert Date and Time to Julian Date or POSIX Time
ref.sum: You can convert datetime arrays to numeric formats that count seconds or days elapsed since the start time for a given format. When you convert a datetime array to POSIX times or Julian dates, the best practice is to specify the time zone before conversion.

ref.name: Create Categorical Arrays
ref.alt: Create Categorical Arrays
ref.sum: Create categorical arrays from various types of input data and modify their elements.

ref.name: Convert Text in Table Variables to Categorical
ref.alt: Convert Text in Table Variables to Categorical
ref.sum: Convert a variable in a table from a cell array of character vectors to a categorical array.

ref.name: Combine Categorical Arrays
ref.alt: Combine Categorical Arrays
ref.sum: Use concatenation to combine categorical arrays.

ref.name: Produce All Combinations of Categories from Two Categorical Arrays
ref.alt: Produce All Combinations of Categories from Two Categorical Arrays
ref.sum: Multiplication produces all possible combinations of the categories from two categorical arrays. This set of combinations is also known as the Cartesian product of the two original sets of categories.

ref.name: Compare Categorical Array Elements
ref.alt: Compare Categorical Array Elements
ref.sum: Use relational operations with a categorical array.

ref.name: Plot Categorical Data
ref.alt: Plot Categorical Data
ref.sum: Plot data from a categorical array.

ref.name: Work with Protected Categorical Arrays
ref.alt: Work with Protected Categorical Arrays
ref.sum: Work with a categorical array with protected categories.

ref.name: Data Cleaning and Calculations in Tables
ref.alt: Data Cleaning and Calculations in Tables
ref.sum: Clean data stored in a table or timetable. Perform computations by using the numeric and categorical data that the table contains.

ref.name: Grouped Calculations in Tables and Timetables
ref.alt: Grouped Calculations in Tables and Timetables
ref.sum: Perform in-place calculations on groups of data in tables and timetables.

ref.name: Create Tables and Assign Data to Them
ref.alt: Create Tables and Assign Data to Them
ref.sum: There are several ways to create tables and assign data to them. You can create tables from input arrays, preallocate tables and fill them in later, or import tables from text files or spreadsheets.

ref.name: Control How MATLAB Imports Your Data
ref.alt: Control How MATLAB Imports Your Data
ref.sum: If you want to control the import process beyond the options provided by the readtable function, such as defining how to handle missing data or errors, then create an import options object before importing the data.

ref.name: Rename and Describe Table Variables
ref.alt: Rename and Describe Table Variables
ref.sum: To rename table variables, use the renamevars function. To add descriptions and units, use the Properties object of a table. Summarize a table using the summary function.

ref.name: Add, Delete, and Rearrange Table Variables
ref.alt: Add, Delete, and Rearrange Table Variables
ref.sum: Add and delete column-oriented variables in a table.

ref.name: Add and Delete Table Rows
ref.alt: Add and Delete Table Rows
ref.sum: Add and delete rows in a table.

ref.name: Clean Messy and Missing Data in Tables
ref.alt: Clean Messy and Missing Data in Tables
ref.sum: Standardize, fill, or remove missing values in tables, and reorganize tables by sorting rows and moving variables.

ref.name: Using Row Labels in Table and Timetable Operations
ref.alt: Using Row Labels in Table and Timetable Operations
ref.sum: Tables and timetables provide ways to label their rows with names and times respectively. You can join, sort, or stack tables and timetables using row labels, with a few minor restrictions.

ref.name: Convert Text in Table Variables to Categorical
ref.alt: Convert Text in Table Variables to Categorical
ref.sum: Convert a variable in a table from a cell array of character vectors to a categorical array.

ref.name: Add Custom Properties to Tables and Timetables
ref.alt: Add Custom Properties to Tables and Timetables
ref.sum: Add custom properties to tables and timetables, set their values, and remove them.

ref.name: Direct Calculations on Tables and Timetables
ref.alt: Direct Calculations on Tables and Timetables
ref.sum: You can perform calculations directly on tables and timetables without indexing to extract their data. All the variables in your tables and timetables must have data types that support calculations.

ref.name: Calculations When Tables Have Both Numeric and Nonnumeric Data
ref.alt: Calculations When Tables Have Both Numeric and Nonnumeric Data
ref.sum: Perform arithmetic operations and call functions on data or groups of data in tables that have both numeric and nonnumeric data.

ref.name: Summarize or Pivot Data in Tables Using Groups
ref.alt: Summarize or Pivot Data in Tables Using Groups
ref.sum: Interpret data based on common characteristics by creating and visualizing a grouped summary table or pivoted table.

ref.name: Perform Calculations by Group in Table
ref.alt: Perform Calculations by Group in Table
ref.sum: Specify groups of data in tables and timetables, and perform calculations by group. Choose a function for group calculations using these recommendations.

ref.name: Tables of Mixed Data
ref.alt: Tables of Mixed Data
ref.sum: Use tables to store mixed-type data conveniently, access data with numeric or named indexing, and to store metadata.

ref.name: Preprocess and Explore Time-Stamped Data Using timetable
ref.alt: Preprocess and Explore Time-Stamped Data Using timetable
ref.sum: Analyze traffic patterns from sensor data using a timetable to organize and preprocess timestamped data.

ref.name: Grouped Calculations in Tables and Timetables
ref.alt: Grouped Calculations in Tables and Timetables
ref.sum: Perform in-place calculations on groups of data in tables and timetables.

ref.name: Add Event Table from External Data to Timetable
ref.alt: Add Event Table from External Data to Timetable
ref.sum: Add events that come from an external data source to your timestamped data, and analyze and plot the results.

ref.name: Find Events in Timetable Using Event Table
ref.alt: Find Events in Timetable Using Event Table
ref.sum: Find events in your timestamped data. Mark events on data plots and use them to analyze trends.

ref.name: Loma Prieta Earthquake Analysis
ref.alt: Loma Prieta Earthquake Analysis
ref.sum: Analyze and visualize data contained in a timetable. Calculate and plot earthquake shock wave speed and acceleration over time.

ref.name: Create Timetables
ref.alt: Create Timetables
ref.sum: Create timetables from input row times and data arrays, by converting arrays, tables, or timeseries arrays, or by importing files with tabular data.

ref.name: Clean Timetable with Missing, Duplicate, or Nonuniform Times
ref.alt: Clean Timetable with Missing, Duplicate, or Nonuniform Times
ref.sum: Clean timetables that have missing, duplicate, or irregular times, and produce regular timetables.

ref.name: Direct Calculations on Tables and Timetables
ref.alt: Direct Calculations on Tables and Timetables
ref.sum: You can perform calculations directly on tables and timetables without indexing to extract their data. All the variables in your tables and timetables must have data types that support calculations.

ref.name: Resample and Aggregate Data in Timetable
ref.alt: Resample and Aggregate Data in Timetable
ref.sum: Resample or aggregate data in a timetable to a new vector of row times.

ref.name: Combine Timetables and Synchronize Their Data
ref.alt: Combine Timetables and Synchronize Their Data
ref.sum: Combine timetables by concatenation or by synchronizing their data to a common time vector.

ref.name: Retime and Synchronize Timetable Variables Using Different Methods
ref.alt: Retime and Synchronize Timetable Variables Using Different Methods
ref.sum: Call retime or synchronize on timetables and apply different methods to fill in or interpolate different variables.

ref.name: Select Times in Timetable
ref.alt: Select Times in Timetable
ref.sum: Select row times from a timetable by using the timerange or withtol functions, or by matching date or time components of the row times. Resample or group the selected timetable data by using the retime function.

ref.name: Using Row Labels in Table and Timetable Operations
ref.alt: Using Row Labels in Table and Timetable Operations
ref.sum: Tables and timetables provide ways to label their rows with names and times respectively. You can join, sort, or stack tables and timetables using row labels, with a few minor restrictions.

ref.name: Rename and Describe Table Variables
ref.alt: Rename and Describe Table Variables
ref.sum: To rename table variables, use the renamevars function. To add descriptions and units, use the Properties object of a table. Summarize a table using the summary function.

ref.name: Add Custom Properties to Tables and Timetables
ref.alt: Add Custom Properties to Tables and Timetables
ref.sum: Add custom properties to tables and timetables, set their values, and remove them.

ref.name: Time Series Objects and Collections
ref.alt: Time Series Objects and Collections
ref.sum: There are two types of time series objects in MATLAB, a timeseries object and a tscollection object.

ref.name: Access Data in Cell Array
ref.alt: Access Data in Cell Array
ref.sum: Read and write data from and to a cell array.

ref.name: Create Cell Array
ref.alt: Create Cell Array
ref.sum: Create a cell array by using the {} operator or the cell function.

ref.name: Add or Delete Cells in Cell Array
ref.alt: Add or Delete Cells in Cell Array
ref.sum: Expand, concatenate, or remove data from a cell array.

ref.name: Pass Function to Another Function
ref.alt: Pass Function to Another Function
ref.sum: You can use function handles as input arguments to functions that evaluate mathematical expressions over a range of values, such as integral and fzero.

ref.name: Call Local Functions Using Function Handles
ref.alt: Call Local Functions Using Function Handles
ref.sum: If a function returns handles to local functions, you can call the local functions outside of the main function. This approach allows you to have multiple, callable functions in a single file.

ref.name: Compare Function Handles
ref.alt: Compare Function Handles
ref.sum: The result of comparing equality of function handles depends on what the handle represents and when you created it.

ref.name: Map Data with Dictionaries
ref.alt: Map Data with Dictionaries
ref.sum: Use dictionaries to store key-value pairs of different data types.

ref.name: Time Series Objects and Collections
ref.alt: Time Series Objects and Collections
ref.sum: There are two types of time series objects in MATLAB, a timeseries object and a tscollection object.

ref.name: Working with Objects in MATLAB
ref.alt: Working with Objects in MATLAB
ref.sum: Some MATLAB functions return objects. Objects combine data with functions and methods.

ref.name: Convert Text to Numeric Values
ref.alt: Convert Text to Numeric Values
ref.sum: Convert text to arrays of numeric values. Text can represent floating-point values, dates and times, and hexadecimal and binary numbers. If text represents dates and times, then you can convert the text to datetime or duration values.

ref.name: Convert Numeric Values to Text
ref.alt: Convert Numeric Values to Text
ref.sum: Convert numeric values to text. Text can represent floating-point values, either with or without exponential notation, or hexadecimal or binary digits. Use these conversions to add numbers to text such as plot labels or titles.

ref.name: Unicode and ASCII Values
ref.alt: Unicode and ASCII Values
ref.sum: MATLAB stores all characters as Unicode characters. Both strings and character vectors use the same encoding. You can convert characters to their Unicode code values, and numbers to characters.

ref.name: Hexadecimal and Binary Values
ref.alt: Hexadecimal and Binary Values
ref.sum: Specify hexadecimal and binary values either as literals or as text. Hexadecimal and binary literals are stored as integers. You can convert text representing hexadecimal and binary values to numbers, and numbers to text representations.

ref.name: Convert Between Text and datetime or duration Values
ref.alt: Convert Between Text and datetime or duration Values
ref.sum: The datetime and duration data types are the recommended data types for working with dates and times. You can convert these data types to text by using the string function, and you can convert text to these data types by using the datetime and duration functions. When you read text representing dates and times from spreadsheets and text files you can automatically convert the text to datetime or duration arrays.

ref.name: Convert Text in Table Variables to Categorical
ref.alt: Convert Text in Table Variables to Categorical
ref.sum: Convert a variable in a table from a cell array of character vectors to a categorical array.

ref.name: Find Array Elements That Meet Conditions
ref.alt: Find Array Elements That Meet Conditions
ref.sum: Filter the elements of an array by applying conditions to the array. For instance, you can examine the even elements in a matrix, find the location of all 0s in a multidimensional array, or replace NaN values in data. You can perform these tasks using a combination of the relational and logical operators. The relational operators (>, <, >=, <=, ==, ~=) impose conditions on the array, and you can apply multiple conditions by connecting them with the logical operators and, or, and not, respectively denoted by the symbols &, |, and ~.

ref.name: Reduce Logical Arrays to Single Value
ref.alt: Reduce Logical Arrays to Single Value
ref.sum: Use the any and all functions to reduce an entire array to a single logical value.

ref.name: Average Similar Data Points Using a Tolerance
ref.alt: Average Similar Data Points Using a Tolerance
ref.sum: Average a group of points that are within tolerance. This approach produces a reduced data set that still holds the general shape of the original data.

ref.name: Group Scattered Data Using a Tolerance
ref.alt: Group Scattered Data Using a Tolerance
ref.sum: Group scattered data points based on their proximity to points of interest.

ref.name: Bit-Wise Operations
ref.alt: Bit-Wise Operations
ref.sum: This topic shows how to use bit-wise operations in MATLAB® to manipulate the bits of numbers. Operating on bits is directly supported by most modern CPUs. In many cases, manipulating the bits of a number in this way is quicker than performing arithmetic operations like division or multiplication.

ref.name: Perform Cyclic Redundancy Check
ref.alt: Perform Cyclic Redundancy Check
ref.sum: Perform a cyclic redundancy check (CRC) on the bits of a number. CRCs are used to detect errors in the transmission of data in digital systems. When a piece of data is sent, a short check value is attached to it. The check value is obtained by polynomial division with the bits in the data. When the data is received, the polynomial division is repeated, and the result is compared with the check value. If the results differ, then the data was corrupted during transmission.

ref.name: Import Data from Text File to Table
ref.alt: Import Data from Text File to Table
ref.sum: The best way to represent tabular data from text files in MATLAB is in a table since tables can store heterogeneous (a mix of numeric and text) data, as well as variable and row names.

ref.name: Control How MATLAB Imports Your Data
ref.alt: Control How MATLAB Imports Your Data
ref.sum: If you want to control the import process beyond the options provided by the readtable function, such as defining how to handle missing data or errors, then create an import options object before importing the data.

ref.name: Import Block of Mixed Data from Text File into Table or Cell Array
ref.alt: Import Block of Mixed Data from Text File into Table or Cell Array
ref.sum: Import block formatted tabular data from a text file into a table or a cell array.

ref.name: Import Block of Numeric Data from Text File
ref.alt: Import Block of Numeric Data from Text File
ref.sum: Read arbitrary block-formatted numeric data from a text file into cell arrays.

ref.name: Read and Analyze Large Tabular Text File
ref.alt: Read and Analyze Large Tabular Text File
ref.sum: Create a datastore for a large text file containing tabular data, and then read and process the data one block at a time or one file at a time.

ref.name: Import Dates and Times from Text Files
ref.alt: Import Dates and Times from Text Files
ref.sum: Import formatted dates and times (such as '01/01/01' or '12:30:45') from column oriented tabular data.

ref.name: Read Collection or Sequence of Text Files
ref.alt: Read Collection or Sequence of Text Files
ref.sum: Read and manage data from a collection of text files.

ref.name: Read Spreadsheet Data into Table
ref.alt: Read Spreadsheet Data into Table
ref.sum: The best way to represent tabular spreadsheet data in MATLAB is in a table since tables can store heterogeneous (a mix of numeric and text) data, as well as variable and row names.

ref.name: Control How MATLAB Imports Your Data
ref.alt: Control How MATLAB Imports Your Data
ref.sum: If you want to control the import process beyond the options provided by the readtable function, such as defining how to handle missing data or errors, then create an import options object before importing the data.

ref.name: Read Spreadsheet Data into Array or Individual Variables
ref.alt: Read Spreadsheet Data into Array or Individual Variables
ref.sum: In addition to importing data as a table using readtable, you can also import data as a matrix, a cell array, or import separate variables directly in to the workspace.

ref.name: Read Collection or Sequence of Spreadsheet Files
ref.alt: Read Collection or Sequence of Spreadsheet Files
ref.sum: Read and manage data from a collection of spreadsheet files.

ref.name: Import HDF4 Files Using Low-Level Functions
ref.alt: Import HDF4 Files Using Low-Level Functions
ref.sum: Read data from a scientific dataset in an HDF4 file, using the functions in the matlat.io.hdf4.sd namespace. In HDF4 terminology, the numeric arrays stored in HDF4 files are called datasets.

ref.name: Import CDF Files Using High-Level Functions
ref.alt: Import CDF Files Using High-Level Functions
ref.sum: Use high-level functions to import a CDF file.

ref.name: Import CDF Files Using Low-Level Functions
ref.alt: Import CDF Files Using Low-Level Functions
ref.sum: Use low-level functions to read data from a CDF file.

ref.name: Represent CDF Time Values
ref.alt: Represent CDF Time Values
ref.sum: Extract date and time information from CDF datasets.

ref.name: Export to CDF Files
ref.alt: Export to CDF Files
ref.sum: Use low-level functions to write data to a CDF file.

ref.name: Read Video Files
ref.alt: Read Video Files
ref.sum: Read frames from a video starting at a specific time or frame index, read frames within a specified interval, and read all the frames in the video.

ref.name: Convert Between Image Sequences and Video
ref.alt: Convert Between Image Sequences and Video
ref.sum: Convert between video files and sequences of image files using VideoReader and VideoWriter.

ref.name: Read Streaming Data from Arduino Using Serial Port Communication
ref.alt: Read Streaming Data from Arduino Using Serial Port Communication
ref.sum: Enable callbacks to read streaming ASCII terminated data from an Arduino® board using the serialport interface.

ref.name: Create App to Display and Log Data from Serial Port GPS Device
ref.alt: Create App to Display and Log Data from Serial Port GPS Device
ref.sum: Connect to a GPS device using serial port and log data to an app.

ref.name: Communicate Binary and ASCII Data to an Echo Server Using TCP/IP
ref.alt: Communicate Binary and ASCII Data to an Echo Server Using TCP/IP
ref.sum: Set up an echo server and communicate with it using TCP/IP by creating a tcpclient object. Binary data and terminated string data are sent to the server and the server echoes the same data back to the client.

ref.name: Communicate with HC-06 over Bluetooth
ref.alt: Communicate with HC-06 over Bluetooth
ref.sum: Communicate with a HC-06 Bluetooth module using Serial Port Profile.

ref.name: Collect Data from Fitness Monitoring Devices
ref.alt: Collect Data from Fitness Monitoring Devices
ref.sum: Collect and plot data from fitness monitoring devices using Bluetooth® Low Energy communication.

ref.name: Track Orientation of Bluetooth Low Energy Device
ref.alt: Track Orientation of Bluetooth Low Energy Device
ref.sum: Track device orientation with device motion sensor data using Bluetooth® Low Energy communication.

ref.name: Log Characteristic Value from Bluetooth Low Energy Peripheral Device Using Callback Function
ref.alt: Log Characteristic Value from Bluetooth Low Energy Peripheral Device Using Callback Function
ref.sum: Access a characteristic of your Bluetooth® Low Energy (BLE) device, create a callback function to read the raw BLE characteristic value for a fixed duration, and log it in a text file.

ref.name: Log Characteristic Value from Bluetooth Low Energy Peripheral Device Using a MATLAB Class
ref.alt: Log Characteristic Value from Bluetooth Low Energy Peripheral Device Using a MATLAB Class
ref.sum: Implement a MATLAB® class and object to collect on demand the value of a characteristic of your Bluetooth® Low Energy (BLE) device for a desired duration.

cat.title: Get Started with MATLAB Support Package for Arduino Hardware

ref.name: Getting Started with MATLAB Support Package for Arduino Hardware
ref.alt: Getting Started with MATLAB Support Package for Arduino Hardware
ref.sum: Use MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to perform basic operations on the hardware such as turning an LED on and off, blinking LEDs and playing sound on a speaker.

ref.name: Measure Temperature and Control Peripherals Using the Arduino Explorer App
ref.alt: Measure Temperature and Control Peripherals Using the Arduino Explorer App
ref.sum: Helps you to use the Arduino® Explorer app to connect to an Arduino board and control attached peripherals depending on the temperature variations.

ref.name: Measure Temperature from I2C Device on Arduino Hardware
ref.alt: Measure Temperature from I2C Device on Arduino Hardware
ref.sum: Learn how to measure temperature from an I2C device on your Arduino hardware.

ref.name: Communicate with SPI Device on Arduino Hardware
ref.alt: Communicate with SPI Device on Arduino Hardware
ref.sum: Learn how to communicate with an SPI device on your Arduino hardware.

ref.name: Push Button Control with 74HC165 Shift Register
ref.alt: Push Button Control with 74HC165 Shift Register
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to collect large number of push button states with a 74HC165 8-bit parallel-in-serial-out shift register. This example uses four push buttons.

ref.name: Control 7-Segment Display with 74HC595 Shift Register
ref.alt: Control 7-Segment Display with 74HC595 Shift Register
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to control a 1-Digit 7-Segment display with a 74HC595 8-bit serial-in-parallel-out shift register.

ref.name: Control LEDs with 74HC595 Shift Register
ref.alt: Control LEDs with 74HC595 Shift Register
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to control multiple LEDs with two 74HC595 8-bit serial-in-parallel-out shift registers.

ref.name: Control Rotary Encoder Knob
ref.alt: Control Rotary Encoder Knob
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to control a 12-step rotary encoder with a built-in push button.

ref.name: Steer Two-Wheel Robot
ref.alt: Steer Two-Wheel Robot
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to steer a two-wheel Arduino-based robot with closed-loop control.

ref.name: Control Servo Motors
ref.alt: Control Servo Motors
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to control a hobby servo motor.

ref.name: Control Motors Using Adafruit Motor Shield V2
ref.alt: Control Motors Using Adafruit Motor Shield V2
ref.sum: Use Adafruit motor shield v2 to control servo motors, DC motors, and stepper motors.

ref.name: Read and Write CAN Messages with Arduino Hardware
ref.alt: Read and Write CAN Messages with Arduino Hardware
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to read and write data from the CAN network using the specified CAN device.

ref.name: Advanced CAN Communication with Arduino Using Vehicle Network Toolbox
ref.alt: Advanced CAN Communication with Arduino Using Vehicle Network Toolbox
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware along with the Vehicle Network Toolbox™ to read and write CAN messages and signals using a CAN database.

ref.name: Overcome CAN Message Buffer Size Limitation
ref.alt: Overcome CAN Message Buffer Size Limitation
ref.sum: You the limitation of Arduino based CAN Nodes by using the automatic periodic transmit feature of Vehicle Network Toolbox™. It also shows you how to overcome the limitation by using the timer feature which is available with MATLAB®.

ref.name: Webcam Controlled Rover Using Arduino Engineering Kit Rev 2
ref.alt: Webcam Controlled Rover Using Arduino Engineering Kit Rev 2
ref.sum: Use Arduino® Engineering Kit Rev 2 to program a differential drive robot that can be remotely controlled by MATLAB® over Wi-Fi® to perform operations such as path following and moving objects with a forklift along with obstacle avoidance.

ref.name: Drawing Robot Using Arduino Engineering Kit Rev 2
ref.alt: Drawing Robot Using Arduino Engineering Kit Rev 2
ref.sum: Use Arduino® Engineering Kit Rev 2 to build and program a robot that extracts line traces from an image and reproduces it as a drawing on a whiteboard. The project uses MATLAB® code to capture an image using a webcam, and then convert it into a set of motor commands using image processing techniques, which drive the robot across a whiteboard and reproduce the captured image as a drawing.

ref.name: Self-Balancing Motorcycle Using Arduino Engineering Kit Rev 2
ref.alt: Self-Balancing Motorcycle Using Arduino Engineering Kit Rev 2
ref.sum: Use Arduino® Engineering Kit Rev 2 to build and program a motorcycle bot that self-balances and maneuvers by itself using a flywheel. The project models the motorcycle with the help of inverted pendulum dynamics and performs inertial sensing to balance the motorcycle by controlling the flywheel, located at the center of the motorcycle.

ref.name: Estimating Orientation Using Inertial Sensor Fusion and MPU-9250
ref.alt: Estimating Orientation Using Inertial Sensor Fusion and MPU-9250
ref.sum: Get data from an InvenSense MPU-9250 IMU sensor, and to use the 6-axis and 9-axis fusion algorithms in the sensor data to compute orientation of the device.

ref.name: Wireless Data Streaming Using BNO055 and Bluetooth and Estimating Orientation Using Sensor Fusion
ref.alt: Wireless Data Streaming Using BNO055 and Bluetooth and Estimating Orientation Using Sensor Fusion
ref.sum: Get data from a Bosch BNO055 IMU sensor through HC-05 Bluetooth® module and to use the 9-axis AHRS fusion algorithm on the sensor data to compute orientation of the device. The example creates a figure which gets updated as you move the device.

ref.name: Plot Position Using GPS Connected to Arduino Hardware
ref.alt: Plot Position Using GPS Connected to Arduino Hardware
ref.sum: Get the geographic location using the GPS module connected on Arduino hardware and plot the location in a map.

ref.name: IoT-Based Automatic Cooling Fan Control Using ThingSpeak and Arduino Hardware
ref.alt: IoT-Based Automatic Cooling Fan Control Using ThingSpeak and Arduino Hardware
ref.sum: Create a ThingSpeak™ channel and use the MATLAB® functions to collect the temperature data from a BMP280 sensor connected to your Arduino® board, and then use MATLAB Analysis in ThingSpeak to trigger the automatic control of a CPU cooling fan kept in the room and then monitor the usage of the fan by calculating the runtime. This example also shows you how to set up an email alert if the fan turns on, by using MATLAB functions in ThingSpeak.

ref.name: IoT-Based Temperature Monitoring Using ThingSpeak and Arduino Hardware
ref.alt: IoT-Based Temperature Monitoring Using ThingSpeak and Arduino Hardware
ref.sum: Create a ThingSpeak™ channel and use MATLAB® functions to collect the temperature data from a BMP280 sensor connected to your Arduino® board, and then use MATLAB Analysis in ThingSpeak to analyze the maximum and minimum temperature. This example also shows you how to set up an email alert if the room temperature exceeds a threshold value, by using MATLAB functions in ThingSpeak.

ref.name: Classify and Count Fruits Using Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense, ThingSpeak, and Machine Learning
ref.alt: Classify and Count Fruits Using Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense, ThingSpeak, and Machine Learning
ref.sum: Collect RGB values of three types of fruits using the APDS9960 sensor embedded in an Arduino® Nano 33 BLE board and use the MATLAB® Classification Learner app to train a machine learning model with the RGB values to classify the fruits. This example also shows how to use the ThingSpeak™ platform for tracking the number of fruits in a box and setting up an email alert if the number of any one of the three types of fruits drops to zero.

ref.name: Identify Shapes Using Machine Learning on Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense Hardware
ref.alt: Identify Shapes Using Machine Learning on Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense Hardware
ref.sum: Use MATLAB® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to identify shapes using a machine learning algorithm. This example uses the Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense hardware board with an onboard LSM9DS1 inertial measurement unit (IMU) sensor.

ref.name: Human Activity Recognition Using ESP32 Board and LSM9DS1 IMU Sensor
ref.alt: Human Activity Recognition Using ESP32 Board and LSM9DS1 IMU Sensor
ref.sum: Classify and predict one of three different physical human activities: Sitting, Standing and Walking based on data acquired using an ESP32 board and an LSM9DS1 sensor. This example uses Classification Learner app to train a machine learning model with the sensor data. To access all the files for this example, click Open Live Script and download the attached files.

ref.name: Perform Predictive Maintenance on Rotating Device Using ESP32 Board, ThingSpeak, and Machine Learning
ref.alt: Perform Predictive Maintenance on Rotating Device Using ESP32 Board, ThingSpeak, and Machine Learning
ref.sum: Predict and monitor the health of a rotating device using machine learning algorithm. You can use this example for predictive maintenance of any rotating device or piece of equipment so that you can fix them before they fail.

ref.name: Calculate Pitch and Roll on Arduino Using IMU Sensor
ref.alt: Calculate Pitch and Roll on Arduino Using IMU Sensor
ref.sum: Read the acceleration and angular velocity data from IMU sensor mounted on Arduino® hardware and calculate the pitch and roll angles.

ref.name: Measure LSM9DS1 Sensor Outputs Using Nano 33 BLE Sense
ref.alt: Measure LSM9DS1 Sensor Outputs Using Nano 33 BLE Sense
ref.sum: Read data from a LSM9DS1 sensor using Bluetooth.

cat.title: Deploy Arduino Functions to Arduino Hardware Using MATLAB Function Block

ref.name: Gyroscope-Based Pedometer Using MATLAB Functions
ref.alt: Gyroscope-Based Pedometer Using MATLAB Functions
ref.sum: How MATLAB Function blocks are used in Simulink® models to implement algorithms using MATLAB® functions. An Arduino® MKR1000 board is used to count the number of steps a person takes while walking. The pedometer is attached to the thigh of the person in such a way that the x-axis of the gyroscope is perpendicular to the direction of walking. The data from a gyroscope sensor is sent to an Android® device using the User Datagram Protocol (UDP).

ref.name: Deploy Arduino Functions to Arduino Hardware Using MATLAB Function Block
ref.alt: Deploy Arduino Functions to Arduino Hardware Using MATLAB Function Block
ref.sum: Program a MATLAB® Function block Simulink® Support Package for Arduino® Hardware to access multiple peripherals on the Arduino® hardware.

cat.title: Troubleshooting in MATLAB Support Package for Arduino Hardware

ref.name: Getting Started with MATLAB Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.alt: Getting Started with MATLAB Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi® Hardware to perform basic operations on the hardware such as executing shell commands, turning an on-board LED on or off and manipulating files using installed MATLAB.

ref.name: Getting Started with Deploying a MATLAB Function on the Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.alt: Getting Started with Deploying a MATLAB Function on the Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.sum: Deploy a MATLAB® function as a standalone executable on the Raspberry Pi® Hardware using MATLAB Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware.

ref.name: Deploy an Edge Detection Algorithm on the Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.alt: Deploy an Edge Detection Algorithm on the Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.sum: Deploy an Edge detection function on the Raspberry Pi® hardware as a standalone executable using MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware. In this example, you will learn how to acquire live image from a webcam connected to the Raspberry Pi hardware, run the edge detection function on the acquired image, and display the result on the monitor that is connected to the same Raspberry Pi hardware.

ref.name: Identify Objects Within Live Video Using ResNet-50 on Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.alt: Identify Objects Within Live Video Using ResNet-50 on Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.sum: Predict the objects in a live video stream on Raspberry Pi® by deploying an image classification algorithm using MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware. The algorithm uses ResNet-50 neural network to identify the objects captured by the webcam that is connected to the Raspberry Pi hardware.

ref.name: Send Inputs to MATLAB Function from Command Line of Raspberry Pi
ref.alt: Send Inputs to MATLAB Function from Command Line of Raspberry Pi
ref.sum: Deploy a MATLAB® function that accepts inputs from command line of Raspberry Pi® using MATLAB Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware. In this example, a MATLAB function for adding two numbers is used for deployment.

ref.name: Send Inputs to MATLAB Function from Command Line of Raspberry Pi in MATLAB Online
ref.alt: Send Inputs to MATLAB Function from Command Line of Raspberry Pi in MATLAB Online
ref.sum: Deploy a MATLAB® function that accepts inputs from command line of Raspberry Pi® using MATLAB Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware in MATLAB Online. In this example, a MATLAB function for adding two numbers is used for deployment.

ref.name: Classify Static Image Using Deep Learning on Raspberry Pi
ref.alt: Classify Static Image Using Deep Learning on Raspberry Pi
ref.sum: Generate and deploy code for an image classification algorithm using MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi® Hardware. The algorithm uses the ResNet-50 neural network to identify the image that is passed as an input using the command line of Raspberry Pi.

ref.name: Speech Command Recognition Code Generation on Raspberry Pi
ref.alt: Speech Command Recognition Code Generation on Raspberry Pi
ref.sum: Generate code and deploy feature extraction and speech command recognition network on Raspberry Pi hardware.

ref.name: Keyword Spotting in Noise Code Generation on Raspberry Pi
ref.alt: Keyword Spotting in Noise Code Generation on Raspberry Pi
ref.sum: Demonstrates code generation for keyword spotting using a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network and mel frequency cepstral coefficient (MFCC) feature extraction on Raspberry Pi®. MATLAB® Coder™ with Deep Learning Support enables the generation of a standalone executable (.elf) file on Raspberry Pi. Communication between MATLAB (.mlx) file and the generated executable file occurs over asynchronous User Datagram Protocol (UDP). The incoming speech signal is displayed using a timescope. A mask is shown as a blue rectangle surrounding spotted instances of the keyword, YES. For more details on MFCC feature extraction and deep learning network training, visit Keyword Spotting in Noise Using MFCC and LSTM Networks.

ref.name: Acoustics-Based Machine Fault Recognition Code Generation on Raspberry Pi
ref.alt: Acoustics-Based Machine Fault Recognition Code Generation on Raspberry Pi
ref.sum: Demonstrates code generation for acoustics-based machine fault recognition using a long short-term memory (LSTM) network and spectral descriptors. This example uses MATLAB® Coder™, MATLAB Coder Interface for Deep Learning, MATLAB Support Package for Raspberry Pi™ Hardware to generate a standalone executable (.elf) file on a Raspberry Pi that leverages performance of the ARM® Compute Library. The input data consists of acoustics time-series recordings from faulty or healthy air compressors and the output is the state of the mechanical machine predicted by the LSTM network. This standalone executable on Raspberry Pi runs the streaming classifier on the input data received from MATLAB and sends the computed scores for each label to MATLAB. Interaction between MATLAB script and the executable on your Raspberry Pi is handled using the user datagram protocol (UDP). For more details on audio preprocessing and network training, see Acoustics-Based Machine Fault Recognition.

cat.title: Build Standalone Applications and Web Apps

ref.sum: Build a digital voltmeter using MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi® Hardware.

ref.sum: Use MATLAB® to process images captured from a Raspberry Pi® Camera Board module to track a green ball.

ref.sum: Build a motion sensor camera using MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi® Hardware.

ref.name: Detect and Track Object Using Deep Learning on Raspberry Pi
ref.alt: Detect and Track Object Using Deep Learning on Raspberry Pi
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi® Hardware to deploy a deep learning algorithm that detects and tracks an object in Connected IO and PIL modes. This algorithm uses the ResNet-18-based YOLOv2 neural network to identify the object captured by the camera mounted on a servo motor and connected to the Raspberry Pi hardware. You can experiment with different objects in your surroundings to see how accurately the network detects images on the Raspberry Pi hardware.

ref.name: Working with Raspberry Pi Sense HAT
ref.alt: Working with Raspberry Pi Sense HAT
ref.sum: Read the sensor values, read the position of joystick and control the LED Matrix on Raspberry Pi® Sense HAT using MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware.

ref.alt: Auto Rotate LED Matrix Display
ref.sum: Use MATLAB® to read the accelerometer on the Raspberry Pi® Sense HAT and control the rotation of the image displayed on the LED matrix.

ref.name: Transfer Data over TCP/IP Between Raspberry Pi Sense HAT and Android Device
ref.alt: Transfer Data over TCP/IP Between Raspberry Pi Sense HAT and Android Device
ref.sum: Use MATLAB® commands to send data over TCP/IP from Raspberry Pi® Sense HAT to an Android™ device and also receive RGB color values from the Android device and display the same on the LED matrix of Sense HAT.

ref.name: Tracking a Green Ball
ref.alt: Tracking a Green Ball
ref.sum: Use MATLAB® to process images captured from a Raspberry Pi® Camera Board module to track a green ball.

ref.sum: Build a motion sensor camera using MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi® Hardware.

ref.alt: Detect and Track Object Using Deep Learning on Raspberry Pi
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi® Hardware to deploy a deep learning algorithm that detects and tracks an object in Connected IO and PIL modes. This algorithm uses the ResNet-18-based YOLOv2 neural network to identify the object captured by the camera mounted on a servo motor and connected to the Raspberry Pi hardware. You can experiment with different objects in your surroundings to see how accurately the network detects images on the Raspberry Pi hardware.

ref.name: Capturing and Stitching Panoramic Images Using ArduCam Multi Camera Adapter Module
ref.alt: Capturing and Stitching Panoramic Images Using ArduCam Multi Camera Adapter Module
ref.sum: Capture images using ArduCam Multi Camera Adapter Module attached to Raspberry Pi® and stitch the images to obtain a panoramic image using SURF feature detection and matching.

ref.name: Deploy an Edge Detection Algorithm on the Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.alt: Deploy an Edge Detection Algorithm on the Raspberry Pi Hardware
ref.sum: Deploy an Edge detection function on the Raspberry Pi® hardware as a standalone executable using MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware. In this example, you will learn how to acquire live image from a webcam connected to the Raspberry Pi hardware, run the edge detection function on the acquired image, and display the result on the monitor that is connected to the same Raspberry Pi hardware.

ref.name: Audio Pitch Shift Using Audio Capture Playback
ref.alt: Audio Pitch Shift Using Audio Capture Playback
ref.sum: Shift the pitch of an audio signal on Raspberry Pi® hardware using audio capture and playback.

ref.name: Audio Event Classification Using TensorFlow Lite on Raspberry Pi
ref.alt: Audio Event Classification Using TensorFlow Lite on Raspberry Pi
ref.sum: Demonstrates audio event classification using a pretrained deep neural network, YAMNet, from TensorFlow™ Lite library on Raspberry Pi™. You load the TensorFlow Lite model and predict the class for the given audio frame on Raspberry Pi using a processor-in-the-loop (PIL) workflow. To generate code on Raspberry Pi, you use Embedded Coder®, MATLAB® Support Package for Raspberry Pi Hardware and Deep Learning Toolbox Interface for TensorFlow Lite. Refer to Audio Classification and yamnet classification for more details on the YAMNet model description.

ref.name: Working with BeagleBone Black Hardware
ref.alt: Working with BeagleBone Black Hardware
ref.sum: You the basics of working with BeagleBone Black® Hardware.

ref.name: Getting Started with MATLAB Support Package for BeagleBone Black Hardware
ref.alt: Getting Started with MATLAB Support Package for BeagleBone Black Hardware
ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for BeagleBone® Black Hardware to perform basic operations on the hardware such as executing shell commands, turning an on-board LED on or off and manipulating files.

ref.sum: Use MATLAB® to process images captured from a web camera on BeagleBone® Black board to track a green ball.

ref.alt: Getting Started with MATLAB Support Package for LEGO MINDSTORMS EV3 Hardware

ref.alt: Improve Steering of Two-Wheel Vehicle Using Closed-Loop Control Algorithm
ref.sum: Implement a closed-loop control algorithm to make a two-wheel LEGO® MINDSTORMS® EV3 vehicle drive straighter.

ref.alt: Detect and Plot Water Level Change with USB Webcam Live Editor Task
ref.sum: Set up your USB webcam to detect and plot the change in water level. Interactively capture images from a USB webcam using the Acquire Webcam Image task in the Live Editor. For more information on Live Editor tasks, see Add Interactive Tasks to a Live Script.

ref.alt: Acquiring a Single Image in a Loop

ref.sum: Use the snapshot function to acquire live images and log the video to disk.

ref.sum: Use the MATLAB® Support Package for Parrot® drone to acquire and plot real-time navigation data of the Parrot drone.

ref.sum: Connect to an FTP server and perform remote operations such as downloading and uploading files, creating and deleting folders, and listing contents on the server.
