ref.alt: Aggregate Data in ThingSpeak Channel
ref.sum: Collect and process data in a ThingSpeak channel

ref.name: Regularize Irregularly Sampled Data
ref.alt: Regularize Irregularly Sampled Data
ref.sum: Update timestamps of data in a ThingSpeak™ channel to remove irregularity.

ref.name: Plot Data Read from ThingSpeak Channel
ref.alt: Plot Data Read from ThingSpeak Channel
ref.sum: Read and Plot ThingSpeak Data

ref.name: Read ThingSpeak Data and Predict Battery Discharge Time with Linear Fit
ref.alt: Read ThingSpeak Data and Predict Battery Discharge Time with Linear Fit
ref.sum: Read data for regression and prediction

ref.name: Calculate and Display Average Humidity
ref.alt: Calculate and Display Average Humidity
ref.sum: Demonstrates how to read data from a channel, analyze the data, and display the result. In the example, you modify one of the code templates provided by the MATLAB Analysis and MATLAB Visualizations apps. The example uses data from ThingSpeak channel 12397, which collects weather data from an Arduino based weather station in Natick, MA.

ref.name: Compare Temperature Data from Three Different Days
ref.alt: Compare Temperature Data from Three Different Days
ref.sum: Read data from an existing ThingSpeak™ channel and generate a plot with three series on the same axis. In the example, as a starting point, you use one of the code templates that the MATLAB Analysis and MATLAB Visualizations apps in ThingSpeak provide.

ref.name: Read and Analyze Large Tabular Text File
ref.alt: Read and Analyze Large Tabular Text File
ref.sum: Create a datastore for a large text file containing tabular data, and then read and process the data one block at a time or one file at a time.

ref.name: Read and Analyze Image Files
ref.alt: Read and Analyze Image Files
ref.sum: Create a datastore for a collection of images, read the image files, and find the images with the maximum average hue, saturation, and brightness (HSV). For a similar example on image processing using the mapreduce function, see Compute Maximum Average HSV of Images with MapReduce.

ref.name: Read and Analyze MAT-File with Key-Value Data
ref.alt: Read and Analyze MAT-File with Key-Value Data
ref.sum: Create a datastore for key-value pair data in a MAT-file that is the output of mapreduce. Then, the example shows how to read all the data in the datastore and sort it. This example assumes that the data in the MAT-file fits in memory.

ref.name: Compute Maximum Average HSV of Images with MapReduce
ref.alt: Compute Maximum Average HSV of Images with MapReduce
ref.sum: Use ImageDatastore and mapreduce to find images with maximum hue, saturation and brightness values in an image collection.

ref.name: Analyze Big Data in MATLAB Using Tall Arrays
ref.alt: Analyze Big Data in MATLAB Using Tall Arrays
ref.sum: Use tall arrays to work with big data in MATLAB®. You can use tall arrays to perform a variety of calculations on different types of data that does not fit in memory. These include basic calculations, as well as machine learning algorithms within Statistics and Machine Learning Toolbox™.

ref.name: Histograms of Tall Arrays
ref.alt: Histograms of Tall Arrays
ref.sum: Use histogram and histogram2 to analyze and visualize data contained in a tall array.

ref.name: Process Big Data in the Cloud
ref.alt: Process Big Data in the Cloud
ref.sum: Access a large data set in the cloud and process it in a cloud cluster using MATLAB® capabilities for big data.

ref.name: Grouped Statistics Calculations with Tall Arrays
ref.alt: Grouped Statistics Calculations with Tall Arrays
ref.sum: Calculate grouped statistics of a tall timetable containing power outage data. The example uses the grouptransform, groupsummary, and groupcounts functions to calculate various quantities of interest, such as the most common power outage cause in each region. Even though the raw data in this example only has about 1500 rows, you can use the techniques presented here on much larger data sets because no assumptions are made about the size of the data.

ref.name: Analyze Big Data in MATLAB Using MapReduce
ref.alt: Analyze Big Data in MATLAB Using MapReduce
ref.sum: Use the mapreduce function to process a large amount of file-based data. The MapReduce algorithm is a mainstay of many modern "big data" applications. This example operates on a single computer, but the code can scale up to use Hadoop®.

ref.name: Find Maximum Value with MapReduce
ref.alt: Find Maximum Value with MapReduce
ref.sum: Find the maximum value of a single variable in a data set using mapreduce. It demonstrates the simplest use of mapreduce since there is only one key and minimal computation.

ref.name: Compute Mean Value with MapReduce
ref.alt: Compute Mean Value with MapReduce
ref.sum: Compute the mean of a single variable in a data set using mapreduce. It demonstrates a simple use of mapreduce with one key, minimal computation, and an intermediate state (accumulating intermediate sum and count).

ref.name: Create Histograms Using MapReduce
ref.alt: Create Histograms Using MapReduce
ref.sum: Visualize patterns in a large data set without having to load all of the observations into memory simultaneously. It demonstrates how to compute lower volume summaries of the data that are sufficient to generate a graphic.

ref.name: Compute Mean by Group Using MapReduce
ref.alt: Compute Mean by Group Using MapReduce
ref.sum: Compute the mean by group in a data set using mapreduce. It demonstrates how to do computations on subgroups of data.

ref.name: Simple Data Subsetting Using MapReduce
ref.alt: Simple Data Subsetting Using MapReduce
ref.sum: Extract a subset of a large data set.

ref.name: Using MapReduce to Compute Covariance and Related Quantities
ref.alt: Using MapReduce to Compute Covariance and Related Quantities
ref.sum: Compute the mean and covariance for several variables in a large data set using mapreduce. It then uses the covariance to perform several follow-up calculations that do not require another iteration over the entire data set.

ref.name: Compute Summary Statistics by Group Using MapReduce
ref.alt: Compute Summary Statistics by Group Using MapReduce
ref.sum: Compute summary statistics organized by group using mapreduce. It demonstrates the use of an anonymous function to pass an extra grouping parameter to a parameterized map function. This parameterization allows you to quickly recalculate the statistics using a different grouping variable.

ref.name: Using MapReduce to Fit a Logistic Regression Model
ref.alt: Using MapReduce to Fit a Logistic Regression Model
ref.sum: Use mapreduce to carry out simple logistic regression using a single predictor. It demonstrates chaining multiple mapreduce calls to carry out an iterative algorithm. Since each iteration requires a separate pass through the data, an anonymous function passes information from one iteration to the next to supply information directly to the mapper.

ref.name: Tall Skinny QR (TSQR) Matrix Factorization Using MapReduce
ref.alt: Tall Skinny QR (TSQR) Matrix Factorization Using MapReduce
ref.sum: Compute a tall skinny QR (TSQR) factorization using mapreduce. It demonstrates how to chain mapreduce calls to perform multiple iterations of factorizations, and uses the info argument of the map function to compute numeric keys.

ref.name: Compute Maximum Average HSV of Images with MapReduce
ref.alt: Compute Maximum Average HSV of Images with MapReduce
ref.sum: Use ImageDatastore and mapreduce to find images with maximum hue, saturation and brightness values in an image collection.

ref.name: Read from Mapped File
ref.alt: Read from Mapped File
ref.sum: Create two different memory maps, and then read from each of the maps using the appropriate syntax. Then, it shows how to modify map properties and analyze your data.

ref.name: Data Cleaning and Calculations in Tables
ref.alt: Data Cleaning and Calculations in Tables
ref.sum: Clean data stored in a table or timetable. Perform computations by using the numeric and categorical data that the table contains.

ref.name: Grouped Calculations in Tables and Timetables
ref.alt: Grouped Calculations in Tables and Timetables
ref.sum: Perform in-place calculations on groups of data in tables and timetables.

ref.name: Missing Data in MATLAB
ref.alt: Missing Data in MATLAB
ref.sum: Handle missing values in data sets.

ref.name: Clean Messy and Missing Data in Tables
ref.alt: Clean Messy and Missing Data in Tables
ref.sum: Standardize, fill, or remove missing values in tables, and reorganize tables by sorting rows and moving variables.

ref.name: Data Smoothing and Outlier Detection
ref.alt: Data Smoothing and Outlier Detection
ref.sum: Eliminate unwanted noise or behavior in data, and find, fill, and remove outliers.

ref.name: Clean Messy Data and Locate Extrema Using Live Editor Tasks
ref.alt: Clean Messy Data and Locate Extrema Using Live Editor Tasks
ref.sum: Interactively preprocess data with Live Editor Tasks.

ref.name: Remove Linear Trends from Timetable Data
ref.alt: Remove Linear Trends from Timetable Data
ref.sum: Remove polynomial trend from data using detrend.

ref.name: Summarize or Pivot Data in Tables Using Groups
ref.alt: Summarize or Pivot Data in Tables Using Groups
ref.sum: Interpret data based on common characteristics by creating and visualizing a grouped summary table or pivoted table.

ref.name: Perform Calculations by Group in Table
ref.alt: Perform Calculations by Group in Table
ref.sum: Specify groups of data in tables and timetables, and perform calculations by group. Choose a function for group calculations using these recommendations.

ref.name: Identify and Visualize Correlated Variables
ref.alt: Identify and Visualize Correlated Variables
ref.sum: Calculate, filter, rank, and visualize correlations between variables.

ref.name: Convert MATLAB Code into Experiment
ref.alt: Convert MATLAB Code into Experiment
ref.sum: Convert your existing MATLAB code into an experiment that you can run using the Experiment Manager app.

ref.name: Experiment with Predator-Prey Equations
ref.alt: Experiment with Predator-Prey Equations
ref.sum: Explore different coefficients and initial values for a system of differential equations.

ref.name: Compare Air Resistance Models for Projectile Motion
ref.alt: Compare Air Resistance Models for Projectile Motion
ref.sum: Calculate projectile trajectories assuming different models for air resistance.

ref.name: Powers and Exponentials
ref.alt: Powers and Exponentials
ref.sum: This topic shows how to compute matrix powers and exponentials using a variety of methods.

ref.name: Graphical Comparison of Exponential Functions
ref.alt: Graphical Comparison of Exponential Functions
ref.sum: An interesting graphical approach for discovering whether e^pi is greater than pi^e.

ref.name: Plot Complex Numbers
ref.alt: Plot Complex Numbers
ref.sum: Plot the imaginary part versus the real part of complex numbers.

ref.name: Predicting the US Population
ref.alt: Predicting the US Population
ref.sum: Extrapolating data using polynomials of even modest degree is risky and unreliable.

ref.name: Create and Evaluate Polynomials
ref.alt: Create and Evaluate Polynomials
ref.sum: Represent a polynomial as a vector in MATLAB® and evaluate the polynomial at points of interest.

ref.name: Integrate and Differentiate Polynomials
ref.alt: Integrate and Differentiate Polynomials
ref.sum: Use the polyint and polyder functions to analytically integrate or differentiate any polynomial represented by a vector of coefficients.

ref.name: Polynomial Curve Fitting
ref.alt: Polynomial Curve Fitting
ref.sum: Fit a polynomial curve to a set of data points using the polyfit function. You can use polyfit to find the coefficients of a polynomial that fits a set of data in a least-squares sense using the syntax

ref.name: Missing Data in MATLAB
ref.alt: Missing Data in MATLAB
ref.sum: Handle missing values in data sets.

ref.name: Basic Matrix Operations
ref.alt: Basic Matrix Operations
ref.sum: Basic techniques and functions for working with matrices in the MATLAB® language.

ref.name: Image Compression with Low-Rank SVD
ref.alt: Image Compression with Low-Rank SVD
ref.sum: Use svdsketch to compress an image while preserving important features of the image.

ref.name: Matrix Exponentials
ref.alt: Matrix Exponentials
ref.sum: Three of the 19 ways to compute the exponential of a matrix.

ref.name: Determine Whether Matrix Is Symmetric Positive Definite
ref.alt: Determine Whether Matrix Is Symmetric Positive Definite
ref.sum: This topic explains how to use the chol and eig functions to determine whether a matrix is symmetric positive definite (a symmetric matrix with all positive eigenvalues).

ref.name: Page-Wise Matrix Functions
ref.alt: Page-Wise Matrix Functions
ref.sum: Simplify code and speed up computations involving stacks of matrices, especially large sets of comparatively small matrices.

ref.name: Random Numbers Within a Specific Range
ref.alt: Random Numbers Within a Specific Range
ref.sum: Create an array of random floating-point numbers that are drawn from a uniform distribution in the open interval (50, 100).

ref.name: Random Numbers from Normal Distribution with Specific Mean and Variance
ref.alt: Random Numbers from Normal Distribution with Specific Mean and Variance
ref.sum: Create an array of random floating-point numbers that are drawn from a normal distribution having a mean of 500 and variance of 25.

ref.name: Random Numbers Within a Sphere
ref.alt: Random Numbers Within a Sphere
ref.sum: Create random points within the volume of a sphere, as described by Knuth [1]. The sphere in this example is centered at the origin and has a radius of 3.

ref.name: Random Numbers and Vectors from Multivariate Normal Distributions
ref.alt: Random Numbers and Vectors from Multivariate Normal Distributions
ref.sum: Generate and visualize random numbers and vectors that are drawn from multivariate normal distributions. This example discusses the steps to generate and visualize random numbers and vectors that are drawn from univariate, bivariate, and trivariate normal distributions. The randn function generates random numbers from the standard normal distribution. To generate random numbers and vectors from a multivariate normal distribution with a specific mean and covariance, you can transform the data generated from the standard normal distribution. Starting from a d-dimensional random variable u=[u1,u2,...,ud] that follows a normal distribution with zero mean and a unit covariance matrix, you can transform u to v=μ+uR. The variable v follows the normal distribution with mean μ and covariance matrix Σ=RTR. The covariance matrix Σ is a symmetric and positive definite (nonsingular) matrix, which indicates that the multivariate normal distribution is also nondegenerate. Therefore, you can perform Cholesky decomposition on Σ to obtain the upper triangular matrix R. A multivariate normal distribution that is degenerate, where Σ is not full rank (or singular), is beyond the scope of this example.

ref.name: Controlling Random Number Generation
ref.alt: Controlling Random Number Generation
ref.sum: Use the rng function, which provides control over random number generation.

ref.name: Managing the Global Stream Using RandStream
ref.alt: Managing the Global Stream Using RandStream
ref.sum: This example shows how to use the RandStream class to control random number generation from the global stream.

ref.name: Multiple Streams
ref.alt: Multiple Streams
ref.sum: Uses RandStream to create multiple, independent random number streams.

ref.name: Resample Image with Gridded Interpolation
ref.alt: Resample Image with Gridded Interpolation
ref.sum: Use griddedInterpolant to resample the pixels in an image. Resampling an image is useful for adjusting the resolution and size, and you also can use it to smooth out the pixels after zooming.

ref.name: Normalize Data with Differing Magnitudes
ref.alt: Normalize Data with Differing Magnitudes
ref.sum: Use normalization to improve scattered data interpolation results with griddata. Normalization can improve the interpolation results in some cases, but in others it can compromise the accuracy of the solution. Whether to use normalization is a judgment made based on the nature of the data being interpolated.

ref.name: Interpolation of Multiple 1-D Value Sets
ref.alt: Interpolation of Multiple 1-D Value Sets
ref.sum: Interpolate three 1-D data sets in a single pass using griddedInterpolant. This is a faster alternative to looping over your data sets.

ref.name: Interpolation of 2-D Selections in 3-D Grids
ref.alt: Interpolation of 2-D Selections in 3-D Grids
ref.sum: Reduce the dimensionality of the grid plane arrays in 3-D to solve a 2-D interpolation problem.

ref.name: Curve Fitting via Optimization
ref.alt: Curve Fitting via Optimization
ref.sum: Fit a nonlinear function to data by minimizing the sum of squared errors.

ref.name: Optimization Solver Plot Functions
ref.alt: Optimization Solver Plot Functions
ref.sum: Describes how to monitor solvers visually.

ref.name: Roots of Scalar Functions
ref.alt: Roots of Scalar Functions
ref.sum: Solve a nonlinear equation of one real variable.

ref.name: Differential Equations
ref.alt: Differential Equations
ref.sum: Use MATLAB® to formulate and solve several different types of differential equations. MATLAB offers several numerical algorithms to solve a wide variety of differential equations:

ref.name: Calculate Tangent Plane to Surface
ref.alt: Calculate Tangent Plane to Surface
ref.sum: Approximate gradients of a function by finite differences. It then shows how to plot a tangent plane to a point on the surface by using these approximated gradients.

ref.name: Solve Predator-Prey Equations
ref.alt: Solve Predator-Prey Equations
ref.sum: Solve a differential equation representing a predator/prey model using variable step size Runge-Kutta integration methods. The ode23 method uses a 2nd and 3rd order pair of formulas for medium accuracy, and the ode45 method uses a 4th and 5th order pair for higher accuracy.

ref.name: Solve Equations of Motion for Baton Thrown into Air
ref.alt: Solve Equations of Motion for Baton Thrown into Air
ref.sum: Solves a system of ordinary differential equations that model the dynamics of a baton thrown into the air [1]. The baton is modeled as two particles with masses m1 and m2 connected by a rod of length L. The baton is thrown into the air and subsequently moves in the vertical xy-plane subject to the force due to gravity. The rod forms an angle θ with the horizontal and the coordinates of the first mass are (x,y). With this formulation, the coordinates of the second mass are (x+L cos θ,y+L sin θ).

ref.name: Sensitivity Analysis of Epidemic ODE Parameters
ref.alt: Sensitivity Analysis of Epidemic ODE Parameters
ref.sum: Perform sensitivity analysis on the parameters of an ordinary differential equation (ODE) system that models the spread of a disease in an epidemic.

ref.name: Solve Celestial Mechanics Problem with High-Order Solvers
ref.alt: Solve Celestial Mechanics Problem with High-Order Solvers
ref.sum: Use ode78 and ode89 to solve a celestial mechanics problem that requires high accuracy in each step from the ODE solver for a successful integration. Both ode45 and ode113 are unable to solve the problem using the default error tolerances. Even with more stringent error thresholds, ode89 performs best on the problem due to the high accuracy of the Runge-Kutta formulas it uses in each step.

ref.name: Solve Stiff Transistor Differential Algebraic Equation
ref.alt: Solve Stiff Transistor Differential Algebraic Equation
ref.sum: Solve a stiff differential algebraic equation (DAE) that describes an electrical circuit [1]. The one-transistor amplifier problem coded in the example file amp1dae.m can be rewritten in semi-explicit form, but this example solves it in its original form Mu′=ϕ(u). The problem includes a constant, singular mass matrix M.

ref.name: Solve System of ODEs with Multiple Initial Conditions
ref.alt: Solve System of ODEs with Multiple Initial Conditions
ref.sum: Compares two techniques to solve a system of ordinary differential equations with multiple sets of initial conditions.

ref.name: Solve ODE with Strongly State-Dependent Mass Matrix
ref.alt: Solve ODE with Strongly State-Dependent Mass Matrix
ref.sum: Solve Burgers' equation using a moving mesh technique [1]. The problem includes a mass matrix, and options are specified to account for the strong state dependence and sparsity of the mass matrix, making the solution process more efficient.

ref.name: Solve Nonstiff ODEs
ref.alt: Solve Nonstiff ODEs
ref.sum: This page contains two examples of solving nonstiff ordinary differential equations using ode45. MATLAB® has several solvers for nonstiff ODEs.

ref.name: Solve Stiff ODEs
ref.alt: Solve Stiff ODEs
ref.sum: This page contains two examples of solving stiff ordinary differential equations using ode15s. MATLAB® has four solvers designed for stiff ODEs.

ref.name: Nonnegative ODE Solution
ref.alt: Nonnegative ODE Solution
ref.sum: This topic shows how to constrain the solution of an ODE to be nonnegative. Imposing nonnegativity is not always trivial, but sometimes it is necessary due to the physical interpretation of the equations or due to the nature of the solution. You should only impose this constraint on the solution when necessary, such as in cases where the integration fails without it, or where the solution would be inapplicable.

ref.name: Solve BVP with Two Solutions
ref.alt: Solve BVP with Two Solutions
ref.sum: Uses bvp4c with two different initial guesses to find both solutions to a BVP problem.

ref.name: Solve BVP with Unknown Parameter
ref.alt: Solve BVP with Unknown Parameter
ref.sum: Use bvp4c to solve a boundary value problem with an unknown parameter.

ref.name: Solve BVP with Multiple Boundary Conditions
ref.alt: Solve BVP with Multiple Boundary Conditions
ref.sum: Solve a multipoint boundary value problem, where the solution of interest satisfies conditions inside the interval of integration.

ref.name: Solve BVP with Singular Term
ref.alt: Solve BVP with Singular Term
ref.sum: Solve Emden's equation, which is a boundary value problem with a singular term that arises in modeling a spherical body of gas.

ref.name: Solve BVP Using Continuation
ref.alt: Solve BVP Using Continuation
ref.sum: Solve a numerically difficult boundary value problem using continuation, which effectively breaks the problem up into a sequence of simpler problems.

ref.name: Verify BVP Consistency Using Continuation
ref.alt: Verify BVP Consistency Using Continuation
ref.sum: Use continuation to gradually extend a BVP solution to larger intervals.

ref.name: DDE with Constant Delays
ref.alt: DDE with Constant Delays
ref.sum: Use dde23 to solve a system of DDEs (delay differential equations) with constant delays.

ref.name: DDE with State-Dependent Delays
ref.alt: DDE with State-Dependent Delays
ref.sum: Use ddesd to solve a system of DDEs (delay differential equations) with state-dependent delays. This system of DDEs was used as a test problem by Enright and Hayashi [1].

ref.name: Cardiovascular Model DDE with Discontinuities
ref.alt: Cardiovascular Model DDE with Discontinuities
ref.sum: Use dde23 to solve a cardiovascular model that has a discontinuous derivative. The example was originally presented by Ottesen [1].

ref.name: DDE of Neutral Type
ref.alt: DDE of Neutral Type
ref.sum: Use ddensd to solve a neutral DDE (delay differential equation), where delays appear in derivative terms. The problem was originally presented by Paul [1].

ref.name: Initial Value DDE of Neutral Type
ref.alt: Initial Value DDE of Neutral Type
ref.sum: Use ddensd to solve a system of initial value DDEs (delay differential equations) with time-dependent delays. The example was originally presented by Jackiewicz [1].

ref.name: Solve Single PDE
ref.alt: Solve Single PDE
ref.sum: Formulate, compute, and plot the solution to a single PDE.

ref.name: Solve PDE with Discontinuity
ref.alt: Solve PDE with Discontinuity
ref.sum: Solve a PDE that interfaces with a material. The material interface creates a discontinuity in the problem at x=0.5, and the initial condition has a discontinuity at the right boundary x=1.

ref.name: Solve PDE and Compute Partial Derivatives
ref.alt: Solve PDE and Compute Partial Derivatives
ref.sum: Solve a transistor partial differential equation (PDE) and use the results to obtain partial derivatives that are part of solving a larger problem.

ref.name: Solve System of PDEs
ref.alt: Solve System of PDEs
ref.sum: Formulate, compute, and plot the solution to a system of two partial differential equations.

ref.name: Solve System of PDEs with Initial Condition Step Functions
ref.alt: Solve System of PDEs with Initial Condition Step Functions
ref.sum: Solve a system of partial differential equations that uses step functions in the initial conditions.

ref.name: Complex Line Integrals
ref.alt: Complex Line Integrals
ref.sum: Calculate complex line integrals using the 'Waypoints' option of the integral function. In MATLAB®, you use the 'Waypoints' option to define a sequence of straight line paths from the first limit of integration to the first waypoint, from the first waypoint to the second, and so forth, and finally from the last waypoint to the second limit of integration.

ref.name: Singularity on Interior of Integration Domain
ref.alt: Singularity on Interior of Integration Domain
ref.sum: Split the integration domain to place a singularity on the boundary.

ref.name: Analytic Solution to Integral of Polynomial
ref.alt: Analytic Solution to Integral of Polynomial
ref.sum: Use the polyint function to integrate polynomial expressions analytically. Use this function to evaluate indefinite integral expressions of polynomials.

ref.name: Integration of Numeric Data
ref.alt: Integration of Numeric Data
ref.sum: Integrate a set of discrete velocity data numerically to approximate the distance traveled. The integral family only accepts function handles as inputs, so those functions cannot be used with discrete data sets. Use trapz or cumtrapz when a functional expression is not available for integration.

ref.name: Calculate Tangent Plane to Surface
ref.alt: Calculate Tangent Plane to Surface
ref.sum: Approximate gradients of a function by finite differences. It then shows how to plot a tangent plane to a point on the surface by using these approximated gradients.

ref.name: Analyzing Cyclical Data with FFT
ref.alt: Analyzing Cyclical Data with FFT
ref.sum: You can use the Fourier transform to analyze variations in data, such as an event in nature over a period time.

ref.name: Square Wave from Sine Waves
ref.alt: Square Wave from Sine Waves
ref.sum: How the Fourier series expansion for a square wave is made up of a sum of odd harmonics.

ref.name: Fourier Transforms
ref.alt: Fourier Transforms
ref.sum: The Fourier transform is a powerful tool for analyzing data across many applications, including Fourier analysis for signal processing.

ref.name: Smooth Data with Convolution
ref.alt: Smooth Data with Convolution
ref.sum: Smooth noisy, 2-D data using convolution.

ref.name: Finite Difference Laplacian
ref.alt: Finite Difference Laplacian
ref.sum: Compute and represent the finite difference Laplacian on an L-shaped domain.

ref.name: Graphical Representation of Sparse Matrices
ref.alt: Graphical Representation of Sparse Matrices
ref.sum: The finite element mesh for a NASA airfoil, including two trailing flaps. More information about the history of airfoils is available at NACA Airfoils (nasa.gov).

ref.name: Graphs and Matrices
ref.alt: Graphs and Matrices
ref.sum: An application of sparse matrices and explains the relationship between graphs and matrices.

ref.name: Sparse Matrix Reordering
ref.alt: Sparse Matrix Reordering
ref.sum: How reordering the rows and columns of a sparse matrix can influence the speed and storage requirements of a matrix operation.

ref.name: Build Watts-Strogatz Small World Graph Model
ref.alt: Build Watts-Strogatz Small World Graph Model
ref.sum: Construct and analyze a Watts-Strogatz small-world graph. The Watts-Strogatz model is a random graph that has small-world network properties, such as clustering and short average path length.

ref.name: Use PageRank Algorithm to Rank Websites
ref.alt: Use PageRank Algorithm to Rank Websites
ref.sum: Use a PageRank algorithm to rank a collection of websites. Although the PageRank algorithm was originally designed to rank search engine results, it also can be more broadly applied to the nodes in many different types of graphs. The PageRank score gives an idea of the relative importance of each graph node based on how it is connected to the other nodes.

ref.name: Partition Graph with Laplacian Matrix
ref.alt: Partition Graph with Laplacian Matrix
ref.sum: Use the Laplacian matrix of a graph to compute the Fiedler vector. The Fiedler vector can be used to partition the graph into two subgraphs.

ref.name: Graphs and Matrices
ref.alt: Graphs and Matrices
ref.sum: An application of sparse matrices and explains the relationship between graphs and matrices.

ref.name: Modify Nodes and Edges of Existing Graph
ref.alt: Modify Nodes and Edges of Existing Graph
ref.sum: Access and modify the nodes and/or edges in a graph or digraph object using the addedge, rmedge, addnode, rmnode, findedge, findnode, and subgraph functions.

ref.name: Add Graph Node Names, Edge Weights, and Other Attributes
ref.alt: Add Graph Node Names, Edge Weights, and Other Attributes
ref.sum: Add attributes to the nodes and edges in graphs created using graph and digraph. You can specify node names or edge weights when you originally call graph or digraph to create a graph. However, this example shows how to add attributes to a graph after it has been created.

ref.name: Graph Plotting and Customization
ref.alt: Graph Plotting and Customization
ref.sum: Plot graphs, and then customize the display to add labels or highlighting to the graph nodes and edges.

ref.name: Label Graph Nodes and Edges
ref.alt: Label Graph Nodes and Edges
ref.sum: Add and customize labels on graph nodes and edges.

ref.name: Add Node Properties to Graph Plot Data Tips
ref.alt: Add Node Properties to Graph Plot Data Tips
ref.sum: Customize GraphPlot data tips to display extra node properties of a graph.

ref.name: Visualize Breadth-First and Depth-First Search
ref.alt: Visualize Breadth-First and Depth-First Search
ref.sum: Define a function that visualizes the results of bfsearch and dfsearch by highlighting the nodes and edges of a graph.

ref.name: Creating and Editing Delaunay Triangulations
ref.alt: Creating and Editing Delaunay Triangulations
ref.sum: Create, edit, and query Delaunay triangulations using the delaunayTriangulation class. The Delaunay triangulation is the most widely used triangulation in scientific computing. The properties associated with the triangulation provide a basis for solving a variety of geometric problems. Construction of constrained Delaunay triangulations is also shown, together with an applications covering medial axis computation and mesh morphing.

ref.name: Spatial Searching
ref.alt: Spatial Searching
ref.sum: This topic introduces nearest-neighbor and point-location searches.

ref.name: Graph Coloring with Grover's Algorithm
ref.alt: Graph Coloring with Grover's Algorithm
ref.sum: Use Grover's algorithm on a quantum computer to solve graph coloring problems. Grover's algorithm, also called the quantum search algorithm, is a fast method to perform unstructured searches. This example applies the algorithm to a problem where a bit string of a given length is classified as valid or invalid, and the goal is to retrieve one of the valid bit strings. The algorithm uses a state oracle to determine whether a bit string is valid. Although this application of Grover's algorithm is not the most efficient method to solve the graph coloring problem in practice, it illustrates how a quantum algorithm can be applied to a well-known problem.

ref.name: Ground-State Protein Folding Using Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE)
ref.alt: Ground-State Protein Folding Using Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE)
ref.sum: An efficient method for using qubits to encode a protein fold on a 3-D tetrahedral lattice [1], [2]. The ground-state is found through a simulated variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) routine. The VQE algorithm uses classical optimization to improve the initial guess of the ground state, and then a quantum computer calculates the expectation value. The final circuit from the simulation is run on a real QPU for comparison.

ref.name: Solve XOR Problem Using Quantum Neural Network (QNN)
ref.alt: Solve XOR Problem Using Quantum Neural Network (QNN)
ref.sum: Solve the XOR problem using a trained quantum neural network (QNN). You use the network to classify the classical data of 2-D coordinates. A QNN is a machine learning model that combines quantum computing layers and classical layers. This example shows how to train such a hybrid network for a classification problem that is nonlinearly separable, such as the exclusive-OR (XOR) problem.

ref.name: Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) Simulation
ref.alt: Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) Simulation
ref.sum: Use Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) simulation in MATLAB® to compute the mean of a function of a random variable. There are a broad range of tasks in finance and economics that depend on Monte Carlo simulation, from option pricing to macroeconomic stress testing. While this example does not explore computational efficiency, research shows that QMC offers a quadratic speed-up compared to classic Monte Carlo methods.

ref.name: Find Prime Factors Using Shor's Algorithm
ref.alt: Find Prime Factors Using Shor's Algorithm
ref.sum:
Apply Shor's algorithm to find the prime factors of a composite number
N
.

ref.name: Solve Max-Cut Problem Using QAOA
ref.alt: Solve Max-Cut Problem Using QAOA
ref.sum: Use the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) to solve max-cut problems.

ref.name: Specify Axis Tick Values and Labels
ref.alt: Specify Axis Tick Values and Labels
ref.sum: Customize the tick values and labels along an axis, such as editing the tick value placement or modifying the tick label text and formatting.

ref.name: Color 3-D Bars by Height
ref.alt: Color 3-D Bars by Height
ref.sum: Modify a 3-D bar plot by coloring each bar according to its height.

ref.name: Highlight Specific Contour Levels
ref.alt: Highlight Specific Contour Levels
ref.sum: Highlight contours at particular levels.

ref.name: Create 2-D Line Plot
ref.alt: Create 2-D Line Plot
ref.sum: Create a 2-D line plot and specify the line style, line color, and marker type.

ref.name: Add Title and Axis Labels to Chart
ref.alt: Add Title and Axis Labels to Chart
ref.sum: Add a title and axis labels to a chart by using the title, xlabel, and ylabel functions. It also shows how to customize the appearance of the axes text by changing the font size.

ref.name: Combine Multiple Plots
ref.alt: Combine Multiple Plots
ref.sum: Show multiple plots together in the same figure, either by combining the plots in the same axes or by creating a tiled chart layout.

ref.name: Specify Axis Limits
ref.alt: Specify Axis Limits
ref.sum: Control where data appears in the axes by setting the axis limits.

ref.name: Create Chart with Two y-Axes
ref.alt: Create Chart with Two y-Axes
ref.sum: Create a chart with y-axes on both the left and right sides.

ref.name: Create Common 2-D Plots
ref.alt: Create Common 2-D Plots
ref.sum: Create a variety of 2-D plots in MATLAB®.

ref.name: Overlay Bar Graphs
ref.alt: Overlay Bar Graphs
ref.sum: Overlay two bar graphs and specify the bar colors and widths. Then, it shows how to add a legend, display the grid lines, and specify the tick labels.

ref.name: Combine Contour Plot and Quiver Plot
ref.alt: Combine Contour Plot and Quiver Plot
ref.sum: Display contour lines and gradient vectors on the same plot.

ref.name: Create 2-D Line Plot
ref.alt: Create 2-D Line Plot
ref.sum: Create a 2-D line plot and specify the line style, line color, and marker type.

ref.name: Add Title and Axis Labels to Chart
ref.alt: Add Title and Axis Labels to Chart
ref.sum: Add a title and axis labels to a chart by using the title, xlabel, and ylabel functions. It also shows how to customize the appearance of the axes text by changing the font size.

ref.name: Create 2-D Line Plot
ref.alt: Create 2-D Line Plot
ref.sum: Create a 2-D line plot and specify the line style, line color, and marker type.

ref.name: Line Plot with Confidence Bounds
